text: this is Alex Ross Perry I'm the writer
and director of clean avert the scene
occurs about two-thirds of the way
through the film you know also about
two-thirds of the way through the week
that comprises this story where
Elizabeth Moses character catherine has
gone to catherine water spin it's
character Virginia's a lake house and at
this point catherine Waterston's
character has told those of his
character that she'll be having this
party and I wanted to use this scene
which is kind of a classic psychological
thriller type of a scene where you have
this moment where you see here the point
of view of the camera is you know
unified to what the Catherine character
is experiencing and you know this is a
really fun classic trick it's a roman
polanski kind of idea and you know Shawn
Williams a cinematographer was able to
figure out when we're shooting this
moving on super 16 of course Polanski
would have been shooting on 35 Shawn was
able to discern you know the lens we
would need to get the same distorted
affect the Polanski would have shooting
on a different film format but the idea
behind creating that POV is to use this
sequence as a subjective experience
where the viewer is experiencing and
seeing exactly what catherine is again
you know right here where you know
people are looking right at the lens and
creating a subjective moment in a in a
small movie like this is the sort of
thing that I find really interesting
especially because the whole point of
this movie and you know my dream of
cinema in general is that the narrative
is fairly object if you don't really
know what to feel about the characters
the film doesn't tell you this is the
point where you feel sad this is the
point where you cry this is the point
where you where you feel relief the
narrative of what's happening here is
very open to interpretation you have
this kind of fantasy sequence these
nightmarish shots that she has which is
a very classic trope of you know the
genre of these psychological breakdown
films there's shots like that and
everything from Rosemary's Baby most
famously to something like let's get
Jessica to death or Carnival of Souls
you always have the you know ghouls
leaning into the camera POV shot and
that's very that's very subjective we're
subjecting the audience in a very
classical Hollywood way you know in the
sense that you go see a blockbuster you
see a Mission Impossible you're on the
plane with Tom Cruise you're right there
with him so you take a shot like this
and a small independent film and you're
right there with Elizabeth you're
experiencing what she is experiencing
but you don't really know what's going
on inside her head in fact it creates
more questions than it gives answers
because the meaning of what's happening
here is intentionally very objective you
know it's very neutral and if you want
to feel that this is a fantasy then you
feel that if you want to feel that this
is you know something that the Virginia
character is doing to her then that's
suggested as well with the previous shot
and you know that type of subjectivity
objectivity and independent cinema is
very fascinating to me because a lot of
independent films kind of use their the
cinema and they use the camera in a very
flat and objective way and then they use
the story and they use the moments to
tell you exactly how to feel and when to
feel it and what's fun for me and
certainly in a film like this where
we're shooting on this you know format
that gives people an instant outdated
aesthetic is letting people feel
something that is very specific to this
film and instantly you know you see the
green of super 16 and you feel this kind
of bygone era of cinema that we were in
love with and that we were definitely
referencing and then the story is very
confusing and it's open to
interpretation and you have this moment
here where we're kind of skipping in
time and these are flashbacks to what's
meant to be last year's vacation and
you know it's very unclear if this is
happening in her head or you know the
kind of hows and whys of this is very
vague and in a way that's fun for me but
the identification with her is very
specific and pointed
